gGnome 0.1
  • Reference

    Finds chromoplexy chains as clusters of "long distance" junctions that each span at least min.span (i.e. distant regions on the reference) have junctions nearby ie within max.dist. We filter to chains that have at least min.num footprints on the genome and involve at least min.num long distance junctions. We keep track of how many "other" (non small dup and non small del) junctions there are in the vicinity for downstream filtering.

    chromoplexy.Rd

    Finds chromoplexy chains as clusters of "long distance" junctions that each span at least min.span (i.e. distant regions on the reference) have junctions nearby ie within max.dist. We filter to chains that have at least min.num footprints on the genome and involve at least min.num long distance junctions. We keep track of how many "other" (non small dup and non small del) junctions there are in the vicinity for downstream filtering.

    chromoplexy(
  gg,
  min.span = 1e+07,
  max.dist = 10000,
  min.num = 3,
  max.cn = 3,
  footprint.width = 1e+06,
  ignore.small.dups = TRUE,
  ignore.small.dels = TRUE,
  max.small = 50000,
  mark = FALSE,
  mark.col = "purple"
)

    Arguments

    gg

    gGraph

    min.span

    minimimum span to define a "long distance" junction and also the span by which major footprints of the event must be separated

    min.num

    minimum number of junctions and major footprints that define a chromoplexy

    footprint.width

    padding around which to define the footprint of an event, note that the outputted footprint only includes the chromoplexy junction breakpoints

    ignore.small.dups

    logical flag (FALSE) determining whether we ignore small dups when filtering on min.cushion

    ignore.small.dels

    logical flag (FALSE) determining whether we ignore small dels when filtering on min.cushion

    max.small

    threshold for calling a local dup or del "small" 1e4

    Value

    gGraph with $meta$chromoplexy annotated with chromoplexy event metadata and edges labeled with $chromoplexy id or NA if the edge does not belong to a chromoplexy

    Contents

    Developed by Xiaotong Yao, Marcin Imielinski.
